item.title: Insights from COVID-19 Datasets Using R
item.description:
The plots below are created using the COVID-19 dataset published and updated daily by Johns Hopkins University on COVID-19 cases worldwide. Feel free to play around with the interactive plots below. You may be able to find some interesting insights on how each of these countries are affected and how they are faring in relation to others.

You can find various interactive tools at the top right-hand side of each graph:

  1. Download plot as png - Saves a copy of the current view of the graph in .png format
  2. Zoom - Select a portion of the graph to zoom in.
  3. Pan - Use the cursor to pan or view different sections of the graph.
  4. Zoom in/Zoom out - to incrementally zoom-in/out using pre-set magnification steps.
  5. Autoscale - reverts back to the original scale of the graph.
  6. Reset Axes - reverts back to original axes range of the graph.
  7. Toggle Spike Lines - draws both vertical and horizontal dotted lines pointing to the x and y values of the datapoint on which the cursor lies.
  8. Show Closest Data on Hover - shows the value and attributes of the datapoint closest to the cursor.
  9. Compare Data on Hover - shows the value and attributes of the datapoint nearest to the cursor and all other corresponding data points of all trend lines that sits on the same x-axis value.
  10. Click on the Name of Each Country on the Legend Section to active/deactive each line trend. Use autoscale for optimized viewing of the chart based on currently active Countries.

item.title: Creating My First Website Using R
item.description:
I came across this twitter post from @dsquintana and this encouraged me to make this personal static website.

"How to make a free personal website in R"

Dan Quintana @dsquintanahttps://t.co/YfWLI0RLvj#rstats pic.twitter.com/x8uNbXaGEr

— R posts you might have missed! (@icymi_r) April 4, 2020

I have tinkered quite a bit on blogdown r package authored by @xieyihui awhile back when I watched his webinar vid. I got reunited to this recently, and now was able to have a complete setup using R Studio, Blogdown, Github, Netlify and Namecheap.

After some few struggles, I am quite happy to have successfully configured the continuous deployment from Github in Netlify.

Here are the key steps that I took to help me bring this site up.

  1. Using R Studio, install the blogdown package install.packages('blogdown')

  2. Create a new project, select “website using blogdown” and type in gcushen/hugo-academic in the Hugo Theme field.

  3. Set-up the relevant files accordingly. Refer to this link for the specifics in setting up the files.

  4. To view the website, you can use blogdown::serve_site().

  5. Setup an account in Netlify where you can host your website.

  6. In case you are a student in an accredited university, you can apply for a free academic domain yourname.me in Namecheap.

  7. Link your Netlify hosted website to your domain in Namecheap.

  8. Create a Github account and upload your blogdown project files to a new repository.

  9. Setup continuous deployment setting from git repository in Netlify.

Note: I intend to update this post with the specifics on each of the steps for reference. Meantime, let me know if you need some more details in any of the above steps
